RESPONSE TEXT: Easy to see why. Those early model synths of theirs strip whole towns for parts, killing everything in their way.
Then you got the newer models, good as human, that infiltrate cities and pull strings from the shadows.
Worst of all, no one knows why they do it, what their plan is, or where they are. Not even me, and I'm a synth myself. A discarded prototype, anyway.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Either way, I need to find Shaun.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You think Raiders might have done this?
RESPONSE TEXT: I honestly doubt it. They can barely organize themselves, let alone pull off something this complicated.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: So you think this Institute is responsible?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Super Mutants? What are they?
RESPONSE TEXT: Big, green, muscles on muscles. In other words, hard to miss. I think we can safely rule them out.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: So you think this Institute is responsible?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Who are the Gunners?
RESPONSE TEXT: High-end mercenaries. No job too brutal. They're in the running as likely suspects, but they wouldn't be the ones pulling the strings.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: So you think this Institute is responsible?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Either way, I need to find Shaun.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're right. This speculation is getting us off track. Let's focus on what you saw. What did these kidnappers look like?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: The woman was dressed in... I think it was a kind of hazard suit. The man had... some sort of metal brace on his arm.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Don't lie to me, Nick. You're one of them. They made you.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yeah, I've heard it all before. "You're a freak", "You've got something to hide," blah blah blah.
But the truth is, people smart enough to build something like me are smart enough to cover their tracks.
And arrogant enough to throw their unwanted trash into the Commonwealth to fend for itself.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Either way, I need to find Shaun.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You don't know anything about them? Really?
RESPONSE TEXT: Some kind of security setting strips or blocks out those memories. And it's not just me.
Any synth that gets trashed, left behind, or escapes the Institute has the same problem. Probably some kind of failsafe.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Either way, I need to find Shaun.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're a prototype?
RESPONSE TEXT: As far as I know. Never seen any other synth like myself.
There's the older ones that are dumb as rocks and all metal, then there's the newer ones that are almost human. I'm somewhere in between.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Either way, I need to find Shaun.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Oh yeah. I heard their names, their home addresses, and where their diary keys are hidden!

RESPONSE TEXT: He's more than just a mercenary. He's a professional. Quick, clean, thorough. Has no enemies, because they're all dead... Except you.
But nine to one odds says he's our man. It's more than just you identifying his distinguishing features. The MO is all him as well.

DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS201Danse: Maxson is the commander of this division of the Brotherhood of Steel.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I refuse to allow the mistakes of the past to be repeated.
RESPONSE TEXT: What you're talking about is going to cost lives. In droves.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'm convinced.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm a bit surprised that you don't realize that by now.
RESPONSE TEXT: It's not heaven, but these people have carved out a life for themselves, one it sounds like you want to snuff out.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'm convinced.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Turning your weapons on the very same people that you're trying to save can be a bitter pill to swallow.
RESPONSE TEXT: Not sure sitting by the wayside is a luxury we have right now.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'm convinced.
SCRIPT NOTES: Quietly angry with the player. / Conspiratorial

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: The difference is our war won't reduce civilization to ashes.
RESPONSE TEXT: Sounds like empty rhetoric to me. "No war is just but mine."
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'm convinced.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Relax, Tom, you'll be all right.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now's not the time to overexert yourself. Save that for if the Brotherhood starts heading your way.
DIALOGUE AFTER: TinkerTom: Right, the whole breathing in and out. OK.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Another of your paranoid fantasies.
RESPONSE TEXT: You talk that way to everyone who lends you a hand?
DIALOGUE AFTER: TinkerTom: C'mon, man, maintain positive energy.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I loved the song. It was perfect.
RESPONSE TEXT: There ain't nothing like real Jazz.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Magnolia: Oh, thank you! A girl tries her best. *chuckle*
SCRIPT NOTES: glad to be in the club listening to good music / Happy

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm not a big fan of jazz.
RESPONSE TEXT: No accounting for taste, I guess.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Magnolia: Shame... but that's all I ever sing here. Goodneighbor inspires a certain kind of music.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Hancock: Good to see you again, Nick.
RESPONSE TEXT: Hancock.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Finn: What d'you care? She ain't one of us.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Finn: Well, well, it's the detective. Tracking down another wayward husband to his mistress?
RESPONSE TEXT: Why, someone stand you up?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Finn: Tryin' that, what d'ya call it? Evasive language, on me?

RESPONSE TEXT: A little bloodthirsty, are we? Fortunately, you picked the right town.
SCRIPT NOTES: dry humor, player kills someone in Goodneighbor, where murder is common

DIALOGUE BEFORE: PrestonGarvey: Let's do this, General.
RESPONSE TEXT: I wouldn't expect a warm reception.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Let's not over-complicate this. Just get in there and hit them with everything we've got.
RESPONSE TEXT: Overwhelming force, huh? Guess that's one way to take 'em down.
DIALOGUE AFTER: PrestonGarvey: If you say so.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm not ready to make a call yet.
RESPONSE TEXT: Don't envy any decision when there's lives on the line.
DIALOGUE AFTER: PrestonGarvey: Sure, take another look around. If you get into trouble we've got your back, but it's better if we go in with a plan.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Let's hit them from both sides.
RESPONSE TEXT: Cook those crabs from all directions.
DIALOGUE AFTER: PrestonGarvey: We'll split up and you can join which ever side you think needs the extra support.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Set up a firing line and I'll draw them out.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now don't think you're going in there without me.
DIALOGUE AFTER: PrestonGarvey: Sounds good. We'll hold back and wait for them to come to us. Just don't get yourself trapped in there.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's pretty ingenious. I bet you can work around the clock.
RESPONSE TEXT: Sure they can. But do you want to?
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Of course, darling. Our unique hierarchy allows for constant operation.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Robots can do simple tasks, sure, but you need a human being to make the big decisions.
RESPONSE TEXT: I think you're forgetting a couple lapses in human decisionmaking.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Ah, but that's where Graygarden is unique, darling.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: This place seems familiar. I think I saw a bit about it on the news, back before the war.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yeah, you're right.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: Yes, construction was completed mere days before the war.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's not even one person here?
RESPONSE TEXT: No wonder it's in such great shape.
DIALOGUE AFTER: SupervisorWhite: That's right, darling. We are entirely self-sufficient, with no need for human guidance.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: SupervisorWhite: Perhaps you've noticed that I possess a rather singular personality, as do the other supervisors.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're no synth, but you sure got panache.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Well, it's definitely unique. Sort of hard to miss.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: It's pretty clever, making a tarberry bog out of an old swimming pool.
RESPONSE TEXT: No kidding. And it's a good lookin' crop, to boot.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Wiseman: I appreciate your saying so.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: The first word that comes to my mind is "ugly."
RESPONSE TEXT: Dunno. I've seen people eat uglier. Though I wish I hadn't.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Wiseman: Hey, do I look like a guy who puts a premium on beauty?
SCRIPT NOTES: Last sentence should be said in a "I've seen some shit" tone. / Neutral

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No wonder your crops are doing so well.
RESPONSE TEXT: Makes me happy I don't eat. But they sure are thriving.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Roger: Yeah, they really are.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't care how fertile the soil is, this place reeks.
RESPONSE TEXT: It this bad everyday or did something pass away here recently?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Roger: Yeah, but you get used to it.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Take the good with the bad, I guess.
RESPONSE TEXT: If that's the silver lining...
DIALOGUE AFTER: Roger: That's how it is everywhere, friend.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What do you grow here?
RESPONSE TEXT: Whatever it is, I don't think it's well.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Roger: We've got mutfruit and tatos for the time being.

RESPONSE TEXT: You know, that whole business with Doc Amari and Kellogg's memories. It got me thinking.
It's just... there's still some Nick Valentine history I've been wanting to put a bow on for a while now.
I could use a hand, if you're willing to take a crack at it.
You know, there is this chunk of Nick Valentine history I've been hoping to put a bow on for a while now.
I could use a hand, if you're willing to take a crack at it?
Any chance you've rethought helping me close out some Nick Valentine history?
So, you rethink helping me take down Winter?
You know, there's another chunk of Nick Valentine history I've been hoping to put a bow on for a while now.
I could use a hand, if you're willing to take a crack at it?
You know, I've been thinking.
What went down with Doc Amari and Kellogg's memories. I'm glad I did it, don't get me wrong.
It's just made me realize that there's still some Nick Valentine business that I've been wanting to put a bow on for a while now.
I was wondering if you'd be up for lending a hand?
Hey. Hold up a minute.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Hold on, you'll make it through.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're not shuffling off on us just yet.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Glory: Bullshit. *cough*

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't have time for this.
RESPONSE TEXT: It's alright, Glory. You're here with friends. And one goon.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Glory: Isn't there... supposed to be a light?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I promise.
RESPONSE TEXT: And our word's as good as gold.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Glory: If anyone... *cough*

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How bad is it?
RESPONSE TEXT: Can we make you more comfortable?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Glory: No escape... this time. *cough*

RESPONSE TEXT: I didn't realize we were pimping ourselves out as a guns for hire now.
Good. I was worried for a second there you were going to do it.
You leave all your scruples in your other coat? Or is this just who you are now? A hitman?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Here you go.
RESPONSE TEXT: Common decency. What a pleasant change.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sheffield: *gasp* Oh thank you! Thank you!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm... gonna go...
RESPONSE TEXT: Sorry, Sheffield. Seems you're going to have to drink dust because my friend can't figure out how to untie his purse strings.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sheffield: *whimpering*

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Drink. Some. Water.
RESPONSE TEXT: Yelling at a guy down on his luck. Where'd you learn your manners?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sheffield: Nuka-Cola...So thirsty...*whimpering*

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You want a soda? Is that it?
RESPONSE TEXT: Wouldn't kill ya to help the guy.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Sheffield: Dugout Inn usually has some... but I can't go there... can't be around booze... Doctor says I can't drink that...

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: The Brotherhood cannot allow those abominations to have a nuclear arsenal at their fingertips.
RESPONSE TEXT: Super Mutants with nuclear weapons. Not going to be able to sleep at night knowing that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS202Maxson: Now... we have a vertibird on standby, fully armed and ready to depart.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If we leave Fort Strong unchecked, we have a potential security threat on our hands.
RESPONSE TEXT: I've seen the kind of damage a Super Mutant can do with just a board with a nail in it. I'd hate to see what they can do with a nuke.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS202Maxson: Now... we have a vertibird on standby, fully armed and ready to depart.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I wish all of mankind shared your sentiment.
RESPONSE TEXT: Can't believe what I'm hearing. No one likes Super Mutants, but it sounds like you two are advocating genocide.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS202Danse: These monstrosities are just another example of man blindly taking a step forward only to wind up stumbling two steps back.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Have you taken leave of your senses?
RESPONSE TEXT: Killing always takes its toll on the killer. I'd know.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS202Danse: These monstrosities are just another example of man blindly taking a step forward only to wind up stumbling two steps back.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Well, it's good to see you dealt with them the Brotherhood way.
RESPONSE TEXT: Seems to me like the Mutants were trying to "Brotherhood way" us right back.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS202Danse: These monstrosities are just another example of man blindly taking a step forward only to wind up stumbling two steps back.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're right, I suppose.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now, let's get to business, shall we? What do you know?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Enrico: I know they've been keeping an eye on him for years. Not sure how they originally found him; probably don't want to know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Look, I had the same intelligence reports as everyone else. No one saw this coming.
RESPONSE TEXT: You were put in a hard spot. But now we're going to fix it. So tell us about this guy.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Enrico: I know they've been keeping an eye on him for years. Not sure how they originally found him; probably don't want to know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If things were different, we might not be here. Not now, at least. But with the situation in the Commonwealth being what it is...
RESPONSE TEXT: That's not something in our control right now. What is, is fixing this. So, what do you know?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Enrico: I know they've been keeping an eye on him for years. Not sure how they originally found him; probably don't want to know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: They thought I'd be able to relate to him, with my scientific background.
RESPONSE TEXT: So much for that plan.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Enrico: I know they've been keeping an eye on him for years. Not sure how they originally found him; probably don't want to know.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: The Institute wants the same things you do. We can find a way to work together.
RESPONSE TEXT: We're trying to give everyone a fair shake here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: MinutemenContact: I don't know about that, but... Look, if nothin' else, you'd best get in there and make sure that man's okay.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I know for a fact they won't hurt that man, and if you get in the way, I'm going to have to take you down.
RESPONSE TEXT: A delicate negotiation isn't the place for strong arming.
DIALOGUE AFTER: MinutemenContact: Woah, look... I'm not trying to get everyone here killed, okay?
SCRIPT NOTES: Quietly angry at the player. / Irritated

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You don't have all the information. I do, and I'm telling you this isn't what it looks like. That man's not in danger.
RESPONSE TEXT: So let's all just calm down...
DIALOGUE AFTER: MinutemenContact: You'd better be right. If you're not, that man's life is on your head.
SCRIPT NOTES: Rerecord. Trying to keep people calm. / Pleading

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You sure you're willing to risk being wrong about this?
RESPONSE TEXT: You don't want to be carrying that kind of weight around for the rest of your days, now do ya?
DIALOGUE AFTER: MinutemenContact: Look, I... I just want people to be safe, y'know? I don't want anyone else dying, or getting' kidnapped or whatever.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'll continue to help, but you owe me an explanation first.
RESPONSE TEXT: So, you gonna spill the beans?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS100Danse: Very well.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: At this rate, you'll be dead within two days. And I want no part of it.
RESPONSE TEXT: You really gonna leave them to swing in the wind like that?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS100Danse: Then there's no need for you to remain here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That all depends. How much are you paying?
RESPONSE TEXT: Hey now. I didn't sign up to be someone else's kill bot.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS100Danse: So you're a mercenary. Typical. Fine. You help us, and I'll see you're compensated for your services.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I want to help but I don't like the secrecy. Who are you? Really?
RESPONSE TEXT: Out with it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS100Danse: Very well.

RESPONSE TEXT: Happy to roll up my sleeves if you think you could use the help.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I'd be glad to help.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Preston: We need someone who can bring the whole Commonwealth together in a common cause. And I think you've got it in you to be that leader.
RESPONSE TEXT: With you at the helm, the Minutemen could be a big damn deal.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Okay. I'll do it.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Okay. I'll do it.
RESPONSE TEXT: Finally, something going the Commonwealth's way.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Preston: Good. Good! Welcome aboard. I feel like this is a whole new start for the Minutemen, and the Commonwealth, too.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No. I'm not your savior. I have my own problems to deal with.
RESPONSE TEXT: Not an easy decision. But maybe one you should consider more seriously.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Preston: I get it. You can't take care of other people's problems when you're still overwhelmed by your own.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Ellie: So, you gonna spill the beans? How did things turn out with Marty?
RESPONSE TEXT: Not great.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Ellie: Was he drunk?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Ellie: Was he drunk?
RESPONSE TEXT: Dead. Made it all the way through Faneuil Hall, too. Went out like a champ.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Ellie: No foolin'. Our Marty made it through Faneuil Hall. Never knew he had it in him... well good for him.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No one likes delays.
RESPONSE TEXT: Particularly not when dealing with precious cargo.
DIALOGUE AFTER: OldManStockton: It's bad for business.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're talking about synths, right?
RESPONSE TEXT: Discretion never was your strong suit, was it?
DIALOGUE AFTER: OldManStockton: Yes, I am talking about synths.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A trader always has to move his merchandise efficiently.
RESPONSE TEXT: Wouldn't want any hiccups in the supply chain.
DIALOGUE AFTER: OldManStockton: Exactly.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: So, is there anyone you like?
RESPONSE TEXT: Because "light on charm" doesn't really quite describe it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: DrCarrington: Oh, I wasn't aware we were competing for Congeniality awards. I thought we were rescuing synths. My mistake.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What's a dead drop?
RESPONSE TEXT: Never read a spy novel, huh?
DIALOGUE AFTER: DrCarrington: Oh, dear lord. A dead drop is a mailbox with a railsign on it.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: There's nothing worse than losing a child. Believe me, I know.
RESPONSE TEXT: It can be a real monstrous world.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Blake: I'm sorry to hear you say so.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If your daughter was that stupid, she got what she deserved.
RESPONSE TEXT: Daughter doesn't seem like the stupid one from where I'm standing.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Blake: You're a real son of a bitch, aren't you?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: (playful bark)
RESPONSE TEXT: Taking up with Dogmeat, huh? You two play nice out there.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Dogmeat: (sad whimper)
SCRIPT NOTES: Friendly. Talking to a dog. / Friendly

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'd be honored to join.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'll follow your lead here. But let's try and keep it light on the zealotry, shall we?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS101Danse: That's what I wanted to hear.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: No, I need to move on.
RESPONSE TEXT: Thanks, but no thanks.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS101Danse: That's a shame.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't know.
RESPONSE TEXT: Not a choice to be made lightly.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS101Danse: It's a big decision, so I understand your hesitation.

RESPONSE TEXT: Won't hear any argument from me. Synths have it tough enough as it is.
You know, got some real nerve. You're damn right synths are machines. But that doesn't stop us from being people.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Your leader was just being cautious.
RESPONSE TEXT: We know we're all on the same team.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Deacon: Exactly. Kind of killed our chance at a friendy first impression, though.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you greet all newcomers like that no one's ever going to help you.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're not gonna put them through the ringer for bein' cautious now, are ya?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Deacon: Don't be too hard on the old girl. She's just looking after her wayward children.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What's done is done.
RESPONSE TEXT: Never would have made it this far without thick skin.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Deacon: A healthy attitude.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Do you really have to be so cagey?
RESPONSE TEXT: Seems charm's at a premium down here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Deacon: The precautions are necessary. In our business, if we underestimate our enemy's capabilities it's game over.

RESPONSE TEXT: That man's dead as dirt, and it's going to be on your head. I hope you realize that.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: About time I got out of this place. Let's go.
RESPONSE TEXT: Heading out with Cait, huh? Hope you know what you're getting into.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Dogmeat: (curious sound)
SCRIPT NOTES: The player is leaving Nick for a new companion of whom he doesn't approve. / Concerned

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Preston: Take care, Codsworth.
RESPONSE TEXT: I'll head for home, then. Good luck.
You two go do the Commonwealth proud.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Preston: Take care, Codsworth.

RESPONSE TEXT: The silent routine isn't getting us anywhere...

DIALOGUE AFTER: Bartender: Bobrov's Best. Is greatest moonshine ever to cross lips, lapochka. Very strong though. Two shots, you pass out on floor... guaranteed.

RESPONSE TEXT: You looking to throwaway some extra caps? Because this'd be the place.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Bartender: If you're unhappy hanging out with your crew, you could always work for me. Good pay and all the free drinks you can handle.
RESPONSE TEXT: I guess that'd make me the first to teach you how to act, now wouldn't it?

About time we take a break, no?
Uh, well, yeah, I suppose I am.
SCRIPT NOTES: Someone just asked if you're one of those Synths. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Friend, you got nothing to worry about. Me and the Institute haven't been on speaking terms for a long time.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Phyllis: And Samuel is at my feet and there's blood everywhere.
RESPONSE TEXT: Hmm, not many clues there.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: I know this must be hard for you. Please, tell me the rest.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: They've got something they use to control us, to make us do things we don't want to do.
RESPONSE TEXT: Hmm, smells like there's more to this story.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Phyllis: Any second now they might send some signal, or I'll see the color orange, or whatever it is they do and BOOM.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Roger: Now he's starting to work on my wife and kids, trying to turn them against me too.
RESPONSE TEXT: A real crisis, you've got here. At this rate, he'll have swayed the scarecrows to his side before week's end.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: They just need to be convinced Bill's wrong. That won't be hard.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I know you're in a tough situation here, but lives are at stake. Please help me.
RESPONSE TEXT: You're not the only one with skin in this game.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: Bill isn't the only one who's afraid. People all over the Commonwealth are talking about this Institute.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: A man's life is at stake, and you're fishing for a bribe? You're pathetic.
RESPONSE TEXT: Pathetic? That's seems awful generous.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: Then I guess this conversation's over.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If that what it takes, fine.
RESPONSE TEXT: Now, you gonna talk?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: Well now, looks like I can help you after all.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You don't care about Roger's family? Not even his children?
RESPONSE TEXT: Have some damn heart.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Cedric: You really aren't from around here, are you?

RESPONSE TEXT: Good luck, General. I hope you find your son.
Something seem off about this place to you? Why no Ghouls in here?

RESPONSE TEXT: This place must've been massive in its heyday.

RESPONSE TEXT: Just how many of these did they need?

RESPONSE TEXT: I... I can't believe what I'm looking at.

SCRIPT NOTES: Looking at a massive metal pyramid. / Question

RESPONSE TEXT: Goodness. Mind your fire down here. Couple stray bullets and this whole place could go up.

RESPONSE TEXT: People have been down here. Recently.

RESPONSE TEXT: Even after all these years, it still feels sacred.

RESPONSE TEXT: Hell of a view.

RESPONSE TEXT: You know, the detective life is a lot less glamorous than the comics had led me to believe.

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, it's certainly in better shape than I expected... thank god.

RESPONSE TEXT: No blood. No sign of gunfire. Have you been up here since the bombs?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Remember, the synths are the primary objective. Harm must be avoided at all costs.
RESPONSE TEXT: This isn't our first rodeo, pal.
DIALOGUE AFTER: X418: Here are the recall codes. Follow me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Easy. I just didn't know there were any other Minutemen out there.
RESPONSE TEXT: You can imagine our surprise.
DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: Yeah, I did take a pretty long vacation after Joe died. Not surprised you never heard of me.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'd like to see you try.
RESPONSE TEXT: You must be joking...
DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: This is going to be fun.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't have time for a dick-measuring contest. What do you actually want?
RESPONSE TEXT: What my crass friend is trying to say is we're in a bit of a hurry.
DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: You kiss your mother with that mouth? At least you're finally ready to get down to business.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you're a Minuteman, how come Preston never told me about you?
RESPONSE TEXT: She'd seemed to suggest you'd all gone the way of the dodo.
DIALOGUE AFTER: RonnieShaw: Garvey? Oh yeah, I heard of him. Took over Hollis's group after the Quincy Massacre. One of the good ones.

RESPONSE TEXT: We'd be in a lot better shape with someone like you in our corner.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Of course I'm not going to go through with it. So how do I deal with it?
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't expect the Institute's going to be thrilled when they find out.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Desdemona: We'll deal with that later. We need to prepare for a Brotherhood assault.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I'm afraid you all have to die.
RESPONSE TEXT: Hold it, you wanna do what?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Desdemona: Deacon vouched for you. I knew I shouldn't have trusted him. Or you. We're not going down without a fight.
SCRIPT NOTES: Upset about the player deciding to kill someone. / Puzzled

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're alive, so what do you think?
RESPONSE TEXT: You aren't getting out that easily.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Desdemona: I don't have time for guessing games. And the Brotherhood could be here at any moment.
SCRIPT NOTES: Wryly. Player just informed someone he's been hired to kill that he's not going to do it. / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: How do I deal with this, Desdemona?
RESPONSE TEXT: You must've prepared for contingencies like this.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Desdemona: Give me a straight answer first. Are you still on our side?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: After all you've done? They'll trust you. And I'll make sure no one else finds out about me.
RESPONSE TEXT: He's got a point.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301Duff: I'm afraid something terrible has happened to her.
RESPONSE TEXT: Chance of survival after a week out there ain't that great for someone not used to roughing it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Don't worry, I'll find her.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301Scara: The whole thing's rather complicated, perhaps I'll explain it to you sometime.
RESPONSE TEXT: Sounds like your parents had some pretty specific aspirations for ya.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Scara: So, now that I've formally introduced myself, perhaps you'd care to tell me why you're here?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Because we care what happens to the Commonwealth.
RESPONSE TEXT: You may not like the Brotherhood, but the people of the Commonwealth shouldn't have to suffer for it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: You know, if anyone else wearing a Brotherhood of Steel uniform said something like that, I'd laugh in their face.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you don't work on Prime, I'll have you shot.
RESPONSE TEXT: Have you gone off your rocker? This is not how we operate.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: You son of a bitch!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If not for the Brotherhood, do it for Doctor Virgil.
RESPONSE TEXT: We can't do this without you, Doctor.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS301Li: What they did to Doctor Virgil was cruel... it was wrong. How could I be so blind?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS301ChildofAtom: That is why they must be safeguarded.
RESPONSE TEXT: Just tell him we're gonna make like an atom and split. He can't argue with that, now can he?
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: It's okay, brother. I'm a Child of Atom, too. I'm part of a church up north. The Nucleus. Near a town called Far Harbor.

RESPONSE TEXT: Sure tore this place to shreds, didn't they?
SCRIPT NOTES: Walking through a large battle field. / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: At least she went down swinging.
SCRIPT NOTES: Looking at a corpse of a woman who attempted to wall herself off in a room to get away from Ghouls. She did not succeed. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: From the look of it, I don't think this one even got his last stand. Just crawled up here and died.
Maxson's not going to be pleased. I look forward to seeing that.
Maxson murdered that man. And we did nothing.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: That Maxson fella seemed like he knew what was best. Maybe you should've listened to him.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player stood by while a friend was executed. / Stern

RESPONSE TEXT: Wouldn't want you to have to disobey orders.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Companion: I wished you had the bollocks to do that yourself. At least it's over with.
SCRIPT NOTES: Player just killed a friend on someone else's orders. / Angry

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: With pleasure. I'll make him pay for lying to us.
RESPONSE TEXT: You totally lost it? You're agreeing to kill a man. A brother.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: I appreciate your cooperation.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I won't do it. Danse deserves a chance to explain himself.
RESPONSE TEXT: From where I'm standing, Danse isn't seeming like the guilty one here.
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: You will do it. This is not up for judgment or debate!

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I don't know what to say.
RESPONSE TEXT: I think it's classically pronounced "no."
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: This isn't a request that requires an answer, Knight. This is a direct order.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Isn't there some other way?
RESPONSE TEXT: You wouldn't even fathom letting him live, would you?
DIALOGUE AFTER: BoS302Maxson: Absolutely not. My decision is final.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: BoS302Haylen: If you're not convinced by what he says, or somehow he's become truly lost to us, then you do what you have to do.
RESPONSE TEXT: What Maxson's asking, it isn't just.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: All right, I'll hear him out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Codsworth: By the way, Concord is nearby, and I've seen people there. I don't know if they can help, but perhaps we should take a look?
RESPONSE TEXT: Don't let this one boss ya around, too much, Codsworth.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Dogmeat: (sad whimper)

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Right behind you, sir.
RESPONSE TEXT: So anyone ask about me down there in the Institute?
DIALOGUE AFTER: X688: He couldn't be in better hands.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Will do.
RESPONSE TEXT: Traveling with Piper's not for the faint of heart. I'd know.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Dogmeat: (sad whimper)

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Roger that.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Dogmeat: (curious sound)

RESPONSE TEXT: I'm not the queasy sort, but for this I'll make an exception.

Not bad.

Hmm. I guess this place seems secure.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Huh. You're a tougher nut than I thought. Tougher than I was.
RESPONSE TEXT: Took me a long damn time to get a feel for this place.
Thank goodness I found Diamond City. It's got its flaws, sure, but it beats the hell out of anywhere else in the Commonwealth.
Course, when I took up there back when, people were just as scared of the Institute as they are now, maybe more.
The massacre of the CPG was still pretty fresh in people's minds at that point, and folks were still losing sleep over the Broken Mask.
Plenty of people assumed I was just a saboteur, moving in to melt down the reactor or poison the drinking water.
But, at the time, they couldn't exactly turn me away.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why'd they let you in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why'd they let you in?
RESPONSE TEXT: Because I'd rescued the mayor's daughter.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Gal of about fifteen, pride and joy of the mayor back then, man by the name of Henry Roberts.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why would you want to live among bigots like that?
RESPONSE TEXT: Couldn't really blame them, given the circumstances. But folks sure started turning the other cheek when I showed up with the mayor's daughter.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Gal of about fifteen, pride and joy of the mayor back then, man by the name of Henry Roberts.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Massacre of the CPG? What's that?
RESPONSE TEXT: The Commonwealth Provisional Government. Years back a group of settlements tried to get together and form a coalition.
Every settlement with even a hint of clout sent representatives to try and hash out an agreement.
Only the Institute sent a representative of their own, a Synth. The man killed every rep at the talks.
The Commonwealth Provisional Government was over before it even got off the ground.
I took up in town not long after. I was damn lucky they didn't just tell me to scram right then and there.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why'd they let you in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Broken Mask?
RESPONSE TEXT: This was long before I'd moved to town, but apparently, some gentleman-type shows up in Diamond City, heads down to Power Noodles.
Guess he didn't like the food because he pulled his pistol and opened fire on the folks enjoying theirs.
When security finally put enough holes in him to drop him, they say he was full of servos and sprockets, just like yours truly.
Seems he malfunctioned, went berserk.
It was the first time people realized that Synths had stopped looking like me and started looking like them.
Considering what these folks went through, I felt real lucky they let me in the front gate at all.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Why'd they let you in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Because I'd rescued the mayor's daughter.
RESPONSE TEXT: Gal of about fifteen, pride and joy of the mayor back then, man by the name of Henry Roberts.
The young miss Roberts decided she'd run off with some caravan hand she'd known for an evening.
Turns out the guy was part of a gang of kidnappers. I didn't even know who I was rescuing, just stumbled on a crying girl and four toughs.
I took her home and the Mayor dubbed me a hero, offered me a place in town. Lots of folks protested, said I was a spy, but he wouldn't have it.
Taking up in the city was tricky at first, but I never tried to hide what I was and people seemed to warm to that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Was it hard settling in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Was it hard settling in?
RESPONSE TEXT: They sure didn't make it easy.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: I started off doing the jobs no one else wanted. I got more banged up being Diamond City's handyman than I ever did living out in the ruins.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Why would you stay in a place where you clearly weren't wanted?
RESPONSE TEXT: There were times I seriously considered going.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: I started off doing the jobs no one else wanted. I got more banged up being Diamond City's handyman than I ever did living out in the ruins.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You're not a spy, right? Testing. Testing. Hello, Institute can you hear me?
RESPONSE TEXT: Hell if I know. If I am, the Institute's plan to gather intel on all the runaways of the Commonwealth has been going off without a hitch.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Was it hard settling in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You took down four guys by yourself?
RESPONSE TEXT: Didn't have to. Back then synths were even more of an unknown quantity than they are today.
I told them I was rigged to explode and started going "beep, beep, beep."
SCRIPT NOTES: Pretending to be a bomb at the end. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Hardest part of that rescue was keeping from laughing as they climbed over each other to get away.
DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: Was it hard settling in?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: They sure didn't make it easy.
RESPONSE TEXT: I started off doing the jobs no one else wanted. I got more banged up being Diamond City's handyman than I ever did living out in the ruins.
But I guess folks never forgot I rescued the Mayor's daughter, so they started coming to me when people went missing.
Wife runs off with a new paramour and takes the rent money with her? Talk to the Synth.
An upset father decides moving him and the kids to Goodneighbor in the dead of night's not the worst damn idea since the bomb? Go get Nick.
After a while, the jobs got so backed up, they didn't even ask me to do the handyman stuff anymore.
Hell, I was so happy to do it, it was months before I started charging anyone.
I never stopped being Nick the Synth, but it was Nick the detective folks came to see.
It was about then that things, things finally started feeling normal.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: It took me a long time to realize that home is where you make it. With some time and effort, this place can be home for you, too.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: NickValentine: It was about then that things, things finally started feeling normal.
RESPONSE TEXT: It took me a long time to realize that home is where you make it. With some time and effort, this place can be home for you, too.
Long story, but I hope it helps. You wanna get moving?

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Is something the matter? You sound upset.
RESPONSE TEXT: What? Oh, no, no.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.
SCRIPT NOTES: Confused when the player asks him if he's upset. / Puzzled

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Can we maybe do this later?
RESPONSE TEXT: Yeah, later's fine.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

RESPONSE TEXT: Wrong? Oh, no, nothing's wrong.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What? Oh, no, no.
RESPONSE TEXT: We've just been traveling a while now, and I figured there hasn't exactly been equitable distribution of information.
I've gotten a decent glimpse into your dirty laundry, but you still don't really know a whole heck of a lot about me.
I figured I'd offer to balance the board. So, there anything you want to know?
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What? Oh, no, no.
RESPONSE TEXT: We've just been traveling for a while now, and I figured especially after all that stuff with DiMA, that you deserve to know more about me.
SCRIPT NOTES: alternate player relationship lines if you already met DiMA / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: So, there anything you want to know?
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: So, who are you, Nick?
RESPONSE TEXT: That's a question I've been trying to figure out myself for a long damn time. I know I'm a synth, authentic Institute handiwork.
But I'm still mechanical, not bioengineered like the fancy synths giving everyone the willies these days. I get tune-ups now instead of check-ups.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You know, I'm not really interested in your past, Nick.
RESPONSE TEXT: Not a problem. Can't say I never offered.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What's with the outfit?
RESPONSE TEXT: After I started the agency it just seemed like the sorta thing a detective ought to wear.
I got some old memories, prewar, faded to all heck, of guys dressed like this, doin' what I do.
Puttin' on the hat and trenchcoat, I figured it let folks know I was serious about the whole thing. "Clothes make the man" and all that.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused at his own naivete. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Guess I felt they made me the man I wanted to be.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: What do you remember about the Institute?
RESPONSE TEXT: It's all pretty hazy from back then, but now and then I get glimpses. Life inside the Institute... they keep you isolated.
A single test chamber was my whole world for years. And someone was always watching. Then one day you wake up on the other side. And that's it.
They've cut you loose. Welcome to the Brave New World... with such people in it.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: But I'm still mechanical, not bioengineered like the fancy synths giving everyone the willies these days. I get tune-ups now instead of check-ups.
RESPONSE TEXT: But my memories, my personality, they're all lifted from some cop who volunteered for an experiment back before the war.
They scanned his brain and copied it onto the hardware that runs between my ears.
Don't know why they chose to make a robot based on some pre-war cop instead of a math genius or a bioengineer.
But hey, maybe that's why the Institute tossed me in the garbage instead of turning me into one of their people snatchers.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: But I'm still mechanical, not bioengineered like the fancy synths giving everyone the willies these days. I get tune-ups now instead of check-ups.
RESPONSE TEXT: You remember when DiMA was talking about the Institute's "personality" experiments?
SCRIPT NOTES: alternate player relationship lines if you already met DiMA

RESPONSE TEXT: My memories, my personality, they're all lifted from some cop who volunteered for an experiment back before the war.

Don't know why they chose to make a robot based on some pre-war cop instead of a math genius or a bioengineer.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: That's terrible. They really just threw you away?
RESPONSE TEXT: Sure did. Was quite the rude awakening.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Have you seen yourself? I don't think it's a hard mistake to make.
RESPONSE TEXT: Can't say you're wrong. Out here, it didn't take long to lose that new synth shine.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Wait? You're a robot? What else have you been keeping from me?
RESPONSE TEXT: Ha. Well, I'm not sure if anyone told you, but there's been a war. Nothing big. I think we'll bounce back just fine.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.
SCRIPT NOTES: Amused by the player's quip. / Amused

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Wait? The original Nick was from my time?
RESPONSE TEXT: Sure was. Which meant, when I finally ended up out here, it was quite the rude awakening.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Sure did. Was quite the rude awakening.
RESPONSE TEXT: I remember waking up one day in a garbage heap, a body in tatters and a head full of memories belonging to a man who'd been dead for 200 years.
Suffice to say it was a confusing couple of weeks.
Folks didn't really know much about synths back then, so when I finally ran into people, they mostly treated me with caution rather than hostility.
But the kids, they weren't afraid.
I think his name was Jim. The first person to actually speak to me after I got the boot from the Institute. My first human contact in this world.
Grilled me for an hour. Once they'd seen I wasn't going to hurt anyone, the other folks in the neighborhood came out to ogle the mechanical man.
It eventually turned into a pretty swell soiree. Local mechanic even gave me a once over, free of charge.
Those people, they treated me like a human being. I've been trying to return the favor ever since.
It's a surprisingly rare trait out here sometimes. Something I've noticed you got a fondness for.
Part of the reason I've stuck around this long.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Sure did. Was quite the rude awakening.
RESPONSE TEXT: I remember waking up one day in a garbage heap, a body in tatters and a head full of memories belonging to a man who'd been dead for 200 years.
Come to think of it, that was probably just after DiMA and I had fought... It was a confusing couple of weeks, all-around.
SCRIPT NOTES: alternate player relationship lines if you know about your past with DiMA / Puzzled

RESPONSE TEXT: Folks didn't really know much about synths back then, so when I finally ran into people, they mostly treated me with caution rather than hostility.
But the kids, they weren't afraid.
I think his name was Jim. The first person to actually speak to me after I got the boot from the Institute. My first human contact in this world.
Grilled me for an hour. Once they'd seen I wasn't going to hurt anyone, the other folks in the neighborhood came out to ogle the mechanical man.
It eventually turned into a pretty swell soiree. Local mechanic even gave me a once over, free of charge.
Those people, they treated me like a human being. I've been trying to return the favor ever since.
It's a surprisingly rare trait out here sometimes. Something I've noticed you got a fondness for.
Part of the reason I've stuck around this long.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: If you're good to people, they'll be good back. That's something I've always believed.
RESPONSE TEXT: Couldn't agree more.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You can't be that naive. You really think you were anything more than a sideshow to those people?
RESPONSE TEXT: I don't doubt that's partly true, but they still treated me better than they had any requirement to. I think it's a lesson worth considering.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, I expect you're about as bored as can be listening to me rattle my skeletons. We should probably head out.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: I wish it was that easy. But it's not.
RESPONSE TEXT: Because I WAS Nick Valentine. I had his memories. His fears. All that poor bastard's hope.
I remember getting the call to head to some lab in Cambridge to get that neurotrans-whatever.
SCRIPT NOTES: A little emotional, recalling the past. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: And the next thing I know, I'm in a trash heap, my family, my home, my entire life, gone. Then I discover, all those things, they weren't even mine.
SCRIPT NOTES: Emotional and a bit upset. / Angry

RESPONSE TEXT: Everything I ever was belonged to Nick. I'd hoped with Winter gone, the last hint of that old world snuffed out, I could finally be free.
But being out here with you, what I finally realized after all this time was that taking down Winter, it wasn't about Nick or Jenny or even you or me.
It was about justice, about doing what's right. And that act of goodness, that's ours. All the good we've done. That's ours and ours alone.
And even if that's the only thing in this world I can ever claim as mine, not Nick's, not the Institute's, but mine, then I can die happy.
And none of it would have ever happened if it weren't for you. I'm not sure I'll ever be to thank you for that.
DIALOGUE AFTER: NickValentine: Well, come on. We're not helping anyone standing around here.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: You don't have to, Nick. We're friends. This is what friends do.

RESPONSE TEXT: About damn time. I'm not sure how much more of this I could witness. I'm going home.

RESPONSE TEXT: I'd say we're pretty darn good, considering what we're up against. But there's always more good to be done.

RESPONSE TEXT: You're trying to make a difference out here. That puts you in the "good" column in my book.

RESPONSE TEXT: Hard to say. You know, some folks are just out for themselves. Some want to help those in need. Jury's still out which camp you're in.

RESPONSE TEXT: Got no major complaints at the moment.
SCRIPT NOTES: Talking to someone you've got mixed feelings for. / Neutral

RESPONSE TEXT: Well, travelin' with you beats bein' held prisoner in some Vault. That's for darn sure. So, yeah, I'd say we're fine.

RESPONSE TEXT: Been thinking about that myself. I suppose we're okay. Feel like we could be doing more for folks out here, but otherwise, we're alright.

RESPONSE TEXT: Freedom Trail rolls through some rough territory. Suppose that guarantees any new Railroad applicants can hold their own.
Flying that ship into the heart of the Commonwealth. Mark my words, the Brotherhood's here to start a war.
Turning yourself into a Super Mutant to survive the Glowing Sea. Can't say Doctor Virgil lacks ingenuity.
I doubt the Institute is going to appreciate us putting down one of their lackeys. We ought to find someone to analyze that chip, pronto.
Do me a favor. Once you're in there, remember the looks on the faces of those Institute goons.
I'd assumed this Institute excursion of yours was gonna be a one-way trip. Sure proved me wrong.
The Brotherhood may have been zealots... but did they deserve this?
The Railroad in the flesh. I always figured there had to be some truth to all those spook stories.
A bonafide agent of the Railroad. What say we go help out some synths?
This place is built like a Vault. Must've been a hell of a scrap when the Institute dug the Railroad outta here.
There's only one reason the Railroad's still here. And that's you.
Bringing down the Prydwen's gonna cost a lot of lives... I suppose a strongly worded letter's probably out of the question at this point.
Bringing down the Institute with its own synths. Almost poetic, isn't it?
SCRIPT NOTES: Initially serious. Then making a joke. / Amused

RESPONSE TEXT: Brotherhood's not exactly known for embracing new technology with open arms. Guess that means I shouldn't ask for a hug then...
Inviting the Brotherhood to our doorstep... I'm getting the feeling we just cracked the lid on Pandora's box...
The Brotherhood has some pretty strong feelings on technology's place in the world. Hoping that's not a sentiment you share.
World's a safer place with those nukes out of Mutant hands. Now we just have to worry about what the Brotherhood's going to do with them.
Not that I'd ever speak ill of my fellow bot, but I don't think another war machine is what the Commonwealth needs right now.
Paladin Danse was a loyal soldier. Finding out he was a synth... that man must be going through hell right now.
What happened back there? Danse deserved better than that and you know it.
So, Danse lives another day and gets to take his leave of the Brotherhood. I'd call that a win on all accounts.
SCRIPT NOTES: Not pleased with the player's actions, but keep this restrained. / Somber

RESPONSE TEXT: All I can think is... why? Honestly? How much of a threat could a dozen or so people in a church pose to the mighty Brotherhood?
One more piece before Liberty Prime's unleashed on the Commonwealth. I hope you're prepared for what's to come.
So the Brotherhood got their war machine. Let's hope they use it wisely. And sparingly.
A synth taking up in Libertalia. I suppose some folks will do anything to get away from the Institute...
Storming Bunker Hill... the Institute doesn't care who they hurt to get what they want, do they?
The Brotherhood versus the Institute. Hard to tell who's the lesser evil here.
The Institute's recruitment process leaves something to be desired.
Your little broadcast has got a lot of people scared. Can't even keep the Institute out of our homes now.
There weren't a lot of folks willing to stand up for the synths of the Commonwealth... and now there's none.
Walking away from a fight with a Deathclaw is no small feat. Nicely done.
It's about time the Minutemen reclaimed the Castle. These folks could use a victory.
Blech. Could you believe that stench? Maybe we should have just let the Mirelurks keep the Castle.
Suppose we know why no one else has managed to reclaim the Castle before now. But taking down Mother Mirelurk was a sight to behold.
Doubt the Mirelurks had any interest in whatever was in this armory Ronnie's describing. Maybe we'll get lucky and find something worth salvaging.
Not a bad haul. Ronnie's weapons should keep the Minutemen armed to the teeth for the foreseeable future.
That's some serious firepower you've set up. God help anyone who takes on the Minutemen now.

DIALOGUE BEFORE: Player Default: Things... didn't end well. We were double-crossed by the client once we had what he was looking for. Still have some lead lodged into my hip.
RESPONSE TEXT: Uh... right. Yeah, it's starting to come back to me... Sorry things ended sour.

We need a way to get there. Let's go talk to Kenji. He knows the waters better than anyone.
Looks like this is Kasumi's room. Let's see if she left any clues about where she went.

So DiMA's got his fingers everywhere on this island. And whatever's in his memories isn't something we can wait for someone else to find.

DIALOGUE AFTER: Player Default: If this thing involves the whole island, then you need help. I can be your problem-solver if you let me in.
